issue.title: Wrong acceleration readings from IMU in rotors

content.raw:
@{5d4999e10fa6d40d14fc61f3} I have checked the accuracy of the IMU and I have not found any issues. How are you obtaining the ground truth velocity? If you are treating the velocity used by the multicopter velocity controller as the ground truth velocity, please note that this is simulating a velocity estimator, and as such, has noise added to it. Differentiating this velocity will amplify the noise making it look like it is an order of magnitude higher than what the accelerometer reads. I have verified this experimentally. 

You can check the accuracy of the IMU with your method by removing the noise parameters from the multicopter velocity controller plugin as well as the IMU sensor of the vehicle.
content.html:
@Carlos Thomson I have checked the accuracy of the IMU and I have not found any issues. How are you obtaining the ground truth velocity? If you are treating the velocity used by the multicopter velocity controller as the ground truth velocity, please note that this is simulating a velocity estimator, and as such, has noise added to it. Differentiating this velocity will amplify the noise making it look like it is an order of magnitude higher than what the accelerometer reads. I have verified this experimentally.

You can check the accuracy of the IMU with your method by removing the noise parameters from the multicopter velocity controller plugin as well as the IMU sensor of the vehicle.

issue.title: Wrong acceleration readings from IMU in rotors

content.raw:
@{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} , Can you please be more specific on how you tested the accuracy of the IMU? Here is how we did the validation, and a plot showing the results:

We have created an Ignition Gazebo plugin and modified the rotor model file to load it. At every simulation loop, we extract in the PostUpdate method of the plugin the actual linear velocity in the inertial frame of the robot and then we differentiate assuming a frequency of 250hz in order to get the acceleration \(since the physics solver is based on velocity stepping scheme there is no acceleration in the state of the simulator\), Once we have the linear acceleration expressed in the inertial frame we add the gravity vector and express the resultant quantity in the body frame of the robot. Attached you will find a plot of the measured IMU signal and what we expect it to be \(in the namespace /im\)

Just to make sure, we are assuming that the transformation between the IMU and the base\_link of the robot is the identity.

You could easily reproduce these results from inside the new rotor velocity controller that you have developed.

I am using a catkin workspace, I really hope that this is not related to the problem.

Parallel to this please fix the other existing [problem](#!/osrf/subt/issues/307/unstable-rotor-control), it is really difficult to work when the robot crashes randomly and you don’t know if its the controller’s fault or a disc access.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2845062503-imu_comparison.png)
‌
content.html:
@Addisu Z. Taddese , Can you please be more specific on how you tested the accuracy of the IMU? Here is how we did the validation, and a plot showing the results:

We have created an Ignition Gazebo plugin and modified the rotor model file to load it. At every simulation loop, we extract in the PostUpdate method of the plugin the actual linear velocity in the inertial frame of the robot and then we differentiate assuming a frequency of 250hz in order to get the acceleration (since the physics solver is based on velocity stepping scheme there is no acceleration in the state of the simulator), Once we have the linear acceleration expressed in the inertial frame we add the gravity vector and express the resultant quantity in the body frame of the robot. Attached you will find a plot of the measured IMU signal and what we expect it to be (in the namespace /im)

Just to make sure, we are assuming that the transformation between the IMU and the base_link of the robot is the identity.

You could easily reproduce these results from inside the new rotor velocity controller that you have developed.

I am using a catkin workspace, I really hope that this is not related to the problem.

Parallel to this please fix the other existing problem, it is really difficult to work when the robot crashes randomly and you don’t know if its the controller’s fault or a disc access.

‌

issue.title: Wrong acceleration readings from IMU in rotors

content.raw:
I created a system that I think does what you described. You can find it in the `fake_imu` branch at https://bitbucket.org/azeey/ign-gazebo/ (clone of ign-gazebo). Can you verify that we're doing the same computation? (line of interest https://bitbucket.org/azeey/ign-gazebo/src/85010befdc8425f936496f2c2ab6f1ac3c959966/src/systems/fake_imu/FakeImu.cc#lines-89). 

This is the plot I generated from commanding the X3C5 UAV velocities of -1 m/s, 1 m/s , 0 m/s in the `x` direction each for 10-15 seconds. The red line is the IMU sensor and the blue line is the computed acceleration based on our discussion here. This is exactly what I expect given the noise characteristics of the IMU sensor.

![fake_imu.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/639173588-fake_imu.png)
content.html:
I created a system that I think does what you described. You can find it in the fake_imu branch at https://bitbucket.org/azeey/ign-gazebo/ (clone of ign-gazebo). Can you verify that we're doing the same computation? (line of interest https://bitbucket.org/azeey/ign-gazebo/src/85010befdc8425f936496f2c2ab6f1ac3c959966/src/systems/fake_imu/FakeImu.cc#lines-89).

This is the plot I generated from commanding the X3C5 UAV velocities of -1 m/s, 1 m/s , 0 m/s in the x direction each for 10-15 seconds. The red line is the IMU sensor and the blue line is the computed acceleration based on our discussion here. This is exactly what I expect given the noise characteristics of the IMU sensor.

issue.title: Wrong acceleration readings from IMU in rotors

content.raw:
@{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} ​, @{5cf75629ff02b50ea27b2817} Thank you very much for your help, we have tested your plugin and it works as expected, the math is exactly what we had,  but there was an error from our side, we had a frequency value where there should have been a cycle duration. 

‌
content.html:
@Addisu Z. Taddese ​, @Alfredo Bencomo Thank you very much for your help, we have tested your plugin and it works as expected, the math is exactly what we had, but there was an error from our side, we had a frequency value where there should have been a cycle duration.

‌
